page.title: 06Transport, Rail, St. Austell
page.content: The main line railway station at St. Austell was built in 1886 by the Great Western Railway. In 1985 twelve people are employed there, seven in the Travel Centre and five on other duties. For most of the year there are 15 passenger trains a day in each direction through St.Austell, but in the summer this rises to 2O, when passenger traffic between Penzance and Plymouth increases by 5O% due mainly to the influx of holiday makers. The principal train service from St.Austell is via Plymouth and Taunton to London and there are through trains to Liverpool, Newcastle and Aberdeen and,on Saturdays, to Brighton. The station opens from 3.3O a.m. until 11p.m. The earliest trains carry the overnight parcels, Royal Mail and newspapers.
